Subjective: Back pain radiating down right leg, thigh, to foot; started 1.5 weeks ago, worsening; unable to sleep and work due to pain; slightly decreased sensation on outside of right lower leg; tingling in same area as pain; no loss of strength in leg; normal sensation in riding breeches area; no issues with urination or defecation; wants to get rid of pain; concerned about possibility of surgery.
Objective: No visible abnormalities in legs or back; no pain on palpation of vertebrae; pain worsens with straight leg raise test on right side; decreased sensation on outside of right lower leg; no differences in reflexes; strength maintained in both legs.
Assessment: Lumbar disc herniation with right-sided radicular pain; no signs of cauda equina syndrome.
Plan: 1. Start pregabalin for pain relief; gradually increase dosage; avoid driving during first week or if experiencing side effects.
2. Refer to physiotherapy for exercises to improve back flexibility and reduce nerve compression.
3. Follow-up phone appointment in one week to assess pain relief progress.
4. Contact GP if symptoms worsen, loss of sensation in riding breeches area, inability to feel need to urinate/defecate, or significant loss of leg strength.
